ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Jeffrey James Stoike  Jeff Stoike

Instructor: Jeffrey James Stoike  I think it's critical that the teaching fellow be able to assist with the ecological and quantitative aspects of the management plan. As a social scientist, Jeff was limited as to how much he could contribute to the class.
Instructor: Jeffrey James Stoike  Jeffrey Stoike

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Phil and Jeff are highly knowledgeable and were available to answer questions and provide guidance when asked. However, it seems that due to unforeseen challenges outside of their control, the course was at times poorly convened/ organized. Coordination with landowners and students was at times a bit lacking.When we asked them questions and asked for help - they were both beyond awesome. However, they at times did not proactively instruct the course. There was limited direction or feedback on our management plans. Perhaps that is the purpose of the course- to self-manage.I learned a lot from the process of the management plan, and I think the field trips in the beginning of the course were critical and helpful. I only wish we had more constructive criticism throughout the design of our plan to support its quality. That said, I think we will deliver a product to our landowner which will be helpful and will fit his purposes.Phil and Jeff are both wonderful and talented people with great intentions - there was just a couple of weeks there where juggling was understandably a challenge.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Field workField tripsWorking with my team
course was a vital component of the forestry curriculum - it allows us to further practice the disciplines (botany, soils, sampling, silviculture, etc.) and practice it on a real property
Opportunity to work on an in-depth, clinical project. Integration of different disciplines important to foresters.
Well-rounded, thorough professionnal training
Biophysical sampling methods and rapid rural assessment

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: More time spent on how to design management recommendations - and feedback on how to integrate multiple goals in recommendations. This is the most important part and we did it last and without very much feedback.The test in the beginning of the course was pretty disheartening/ demoralizing for those of us who had not taken taxonomy or geology or done crew. I think it would be best placed a bit later in the semester to give students time to gain some command over the material.

professor was unorganized and not available for assistancefor example, we realized after the fact that several aspects of our sampling methodology were somewhat unecesary or very time consuming, while we neglected other aspects (merchantable timber). these are the things that the instructor or TA should have been able to help withmany class sessions did not provide relevant background for the project

The course was poorly organized. Deadline were not enforced. There were frequent changes to the schedule, which were inadequately communicated to the class. Students received inadequate feedback and direction from the instructor.

It was Dr. Marshall's first year teaching it. Sometimes we felt like he should have challenged us more. Not a lot of feedback provided on our work. A good synthesis for the MF program (it truly should be our capstone) but I didn't feel like I learned a lot. Could have learned a lot with the stakeholder analysis part, but with small landowners there's just not a lot going on.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Field Trips -our property owner did not seem very enthusiastic about the project as a whole. i wonder what kind of selection process we had for the properties

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Jeffrey James Stoike  Great guy, but not qualified to TA this class. The class should be TA'd by someone trained as a forester.
Instructor: Jeffrey James Stoike  Jeff is a great social scientist and a great guy. It's too bad he had stuff going on this semester.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This was a critical course for gaining experience in field work, landowner interests, biophysical analysis, and writing land management recommendations. It is the most important course I have taken for gaining applicable experience with forest management.
see above -course is a crucial integration of all aspects of the forestry curriculum. however, we did not have much support for our field work and data analysis
This class is critical in integrating the different material learned through the MF curriculum.

Like I said, should be the MF capstone. I know Ashton teaches Silviculture in the Spring and can't possibly do both Silvi AND Mgmt but this class is the only time we get to use everything we have learned in real life conditions.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to learn how to create fact-based plans for positive stewardship - I wanted to integrate previous courses - I wanted to work with my colleagues to learn
I regard this class as the culmination of the MF degree.

See answer above. I would feel like a complete fraud showing up at my future office without having written at least one management plan. It's like applying to a finance job without having ever used Excelin your life.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
I thought I'd learn more, particularly about silviculture.

Not really but maybe my expectations are the issue.The reinforcement value was great: a lot of things I had already done in Forest Crew or Silviculture, but if you don't use it, you lose it. The sampling design, the stand delineation, the forest health assessment and so on.The best part was the relationship to landowners. Present them with alternatives you came up with, advise them, establish trust, understand their goals and value and work from there. True bottom-up service forestry, a great lesson in humility, but also a lot of freedom on our side to come up with creative solutions.Too bad that I relied on my partner too much to do things I didn't already know (geology and soils). There's just not a lot of time to teach yourself new tools and still get the job done.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Great way to learn in this type of project
group work was important - project taught us how to work as a team
I had a great experience working with my group.

Advantages were teaming up with a great partner, amazing worker and amazing friend. Some discussion at the end on the things that mattered (silvicultural prescriptions), which is good, but no waste of time discussing sampling or species ID. So, well, no disadvantages at all.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Do it
Be aggressive about soliciting feedback from faculty.
As the French say: Hasten slowly, and without losing heart, put your work twenty times upon the anvil.
